concepts.name: Personal Knowledge Management (PKM)
concepts.summary: The practice of managing personal information and knowledge to enhance learning, productivity, and growth.
concepts.explanation: Personal Knowledge Management is the practice of applying Knowledge Management principles to manage personal information and knowledge, enhancing one's own learning, productivity, and self-improvement. It involves techniques for acquiring, organizing, and applying knowledge in ways that improve effectiveness and fulfillment. Through digital tools and methodologies like note-taking systems, knowledge bases, and personal information management systems, individuals create a structured approach to managing their knowledge. PKM helps empower individuals, store and organize knowledge outside of the head, create a reliable single source of truth, enable deep thinking, connect ideas, accelerate learning, transform information into wisdom, leverage knowledge, and create compounding value.

articles.title: Why is Personal Knowledge Management (PKM) useful
12 Common Personal Knowledge Management Mistakes
Build Your Knowledge System for Decades, Not Months

concepts.name: Zettelkasten Method
concepts.summary: A note-taking and knowledge management method based on interconnected atomic notes.
concepts.explanation: The Zettelkasten method, developed by German sociologist Niklas Luhmann, is a knowledge management system based on creating small, atomic notes that are interconnected through links. Using his Zettelkasten (which means 'slip box' in German), Luhmann managed to publish more than 70 books and hundreds of articles. The method is both a structure (composed of an Inbox, Literature notes archive, and Permanent notes archive) and a process for capturing, exploring, storing, and organizing ideas. It puts focus on connecting ideas rather than accumulating isolated pieces of information, helping to build a deep Web of Knowledge that aids in research, writing, and idea development.

articles.title: Boost Your Creativity With The Zettelkasten Method

concepts.name: Second Brain
concepts.summary: A methodology for saving and systematically organizing your ideas and insights using digital tools.
concepts.explanation: Building a Second Brain (BASB) is a methodology created by Tiago Forte for capturing, organizing, and sharing knowledge using digital tools. It emphasizes capturing information that resonates with you, organizing it for actionability, and regularly reviewing and using your notes to create new content. A second brain is a digital archive of your most valuable memories, ideas, and knowledge to help you do your job, run your business, and manage your life without having to keep every detail in your head. It aims to help you forget intentionally while retaining what matters forever.

concepts.name: Atomic Notes
concepts.summary: The principle of creating notes that capture a single, self-contained idea.
concepts.explanation: Atomic notes focus on a single idea or concept, with the goal of explaining one thing well. Following the Zettelkasten method, notes should be atomic and link to each other, with longer texts assembled by composing atomic notes together. Atomic notes are foundational for building a solid, scalable and maintainable Personal Knowledge Graph. By breaking down knowledge into its most essential components, atomic notes enable flexibility, objectivity, and interconnectivity. They are inherently concise, focused, and flexible - each note becomes a building block that can easily be reorganized, linked, or expanded. Like DNA strands recombining to form new life forms, atomic notes can be linked in novel ways to generate insights.

articles.title: Embracing Fluidity in Knowledge Management

concepts.name: PARA Method
concepts.summary: An organization system using Projects, Areas, Resources, and Archives.
concepts.explanation: The P.A.R.A method was introduced and popularized by Tiago Forte, a productivity expert known for Building a Second Brain. PARA stands for Projects (ongoing work with goals and deadlines), Areas (roles and responsibilities without end dates), Resources (reference material and inspiration), and Archives (inactive items from the other categories). PARA provides a simple skeleton to organize information consistently across any tool or platform - from note-taking apps to file systems to bookmarks. Its benefits include simplicity, flexibility, flat structure for easy navigation, scalability, and cross-platform applicability.

articles.title: Organize Anything With The PARA Method

references.title: The PARA Method by Tiago Forte

concepts.name: Knowledge Graph
concepts.summary: A network representation of interconnected knowledge and concepts.
concepts.explanation: A Knowledge Graph (KG) represents knowledge as a network of interconnected nodes and relationships. In the context of Personal Knowledge Management, your Personal Knowledge Graph (PKG) is the web of connected notes, ideas, and concepts in your knowledge base. Unlike hierarchical folder structures, knowledge graphs emphasize connections and relationships between ideas. The more notes and links you have, the more possible paths exist through your knowledge base - the number of paths grows exponentially. This networked approach mirrors how the brain naturally associates and connects information.

articles.title: Personal Knowledge Management at Scale: Analyzing 8,000 Notes and 64,000 Links

concepts.name: LIFT Principle
concepts.summary: Locatable, Identifiable, Flat structure, Try to stay DRY.
concepts.explanation: The LIFT principle originated from Google's Angular code style guides but applies excellently to PKM and Information Management. LIFT stands for: Locate (quickly find what you need), Identify (easily recognize what things are), Flat structure as long as possible (avoid deep nesting), and Try to stay DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself, avoid duplicating information). This principle ensures that file and folder structures remain manageable, information is easy to find, and duplication is minimized. It's a key design principle for organizing any information system.

articles.title: Organize Everything With The LIFT principle

concepts.name: FILE Framework
concepts.summary: Information should be easy to File, Identify, Locate, and Retrieve.
concepts.explanation: The FILE Framework is a mnemonic created by SÃ©bastien Dubois to help people think about important aspects when designing an information management system. Information in your system should be: Easy to File (F), Easy to Identify (I), Easy to Locate (L), and Easy to Retrieve (E). This framework is designed to be flexible and adaptable, applicable to various information management systems from simple note-taking apps to complex knowledge bases. It can be used to evaluate existing systems, design new ones, or assess potential tools before adoption.

articles.title: Introducing the FILE Framework for Information and Knowledge Management

concepts.name: Johnny Decimal System
concepts.summary: A hierarchical decimal classification system for organizing information.
concepts.explanation: The Johnny Decimal System, created by Johnny Noble and inspired by the Dewey Decimal System, provides a framework for organizing information. It's a three-step process: 1) Divide everything into at most 10 areas, 2) Within each area, create at most 10 categories, 3) Assign unique numbers (areas: 10, 20, 30...; categories: 11, 12, 13...). The core idea is to group related information together with strict limits to keep things simple and manageable. Benefits include clear structure, easy location and identification, logical ordering (not alphabetical), and cross-platform applicability. Nothing is more than two clicks away.

articles.title: Organize Anything With The Johnny Decimal System

concepts.name: Map of Content (MoC)
concepts.summary: Curated navigation hubs that organize and connect related notes.
concepts.explanation: A Map of Content (MoC), concept introduced by Nick Milo, is a note containing links to other notes - a meta note that serves as an index for a specific topic, question, perspective, or area of interest. While each note can only be stored in a single folder, many MoCs can link to the same note, making MoCs like 'folders on steroids.' If links are roads, tags are road signs, folders are houses, then MoCs are maps. They help locate content across the knowledge base, aggregate and connect ideas, keep the knowledge base manageable as it scales, and add context to links. You can even create a 'MoC of MoCs' to express ideas at the intersection of multiple topics.

articles.title: Maps of Content (MoCs) for better Knowledge Graphs

references.title: A Case for MOCs - Obsidian Forum

concepts.name: Fleeting Notes
concepts.summary: Quick, temporary captures of thoughts and ideas for later processing.
concepts.explanation: Fleeting notes are raw, unpolished notes where you temporarily store thoughts, ideas, facts, and questions when you don't have time to do more. They're like writing on the corner of a piece of paper - the quality doesn't matter much, only that you can understand what you meant later. Fleeting notes are transient by nature and you should avoid accumulating them. They need to be regularly reviewed (ideally daily) and either removed or turned into literature or permanent notes. The goal is to maintain Inbox Zero for fleeting notes to avoid feeling overwhelmed.

concepts.name: Literature Notes
concepts.summary: Notes capturing ideas from external sources like books, articles, and videos.
concepts.explanation: Literature notes are where you store notes about everything that inspires you - verbatim quotes, information about people, interesting tweets, book notes, fascinating articles, etc. They represent your inspiration, not your own content. Taking literature notes requires more time and effort than fleeting notes because they're here to stay. The goal is to capture the essence of what inspires you, ideally in your own words, representing your own interpretation. Build the habit of capturing what you find interesting, but be mindful of the Collector's Fallacy.

articles.title: How to capture book notes and turn those into smart notes
Why you should take notes while reading non-fiction books

concepts.name: Permanent Notes
concepts.summary: Your own thoughts, ideas, and interpretations - the most valuable notes in your system.
concepts.explanation: Permanent notes are the most important part of the Zettelkasten method. They represent your own thoughts, ideas, interpretations, and quotes - your own knowledge base. Permanent notes should be well-written, using full and clear sentences, easy to understand by your future self without additional context. They should be atomic (focused on one idea), 100% yours (even if inspired by others), and connected to other notes. Writing permanent notes means writing what you know, what you think, and what you care about. Over time, these interconnected permanent notes form your Web of Knowledge.

concepts.name: Evergreen Notes
concepts.summary: Notes that grow and improve over time through continuous refinement.
concepts.explanation: Evergreen notes are notes that evolve and improve over time, never considered final. Unlike traditional static notes, evergreen notes are continuously refined, updated, and connected as understanding deepens. This iterative approach treats notes as cattle rather than pets - fluid, adaptable, and part of a larger system. The world changes, your knowledge evolves, and notes should reflect your thinking at any given point in time. Never hesitate to update or remove existing notes.

articles.title: Embracing Fluidity in Knowledge Management

concepts.name: Getting Things Done (GTD)
concepts.summary: A productivity methodology for capturing, organizing, and completing tasks.
concepts.explanation: Getting Things Done (GTD) is a productivity and knowledge management method created by David Allen. The core principle is that anything that keeps stuff out of your head because it has captured it and is trusted to remind you appropriately, is GTD. The method involves capturing everything that has your attention, clarifying what each item means and what to do about it, organizing reminders and information, reflecting on the system regularly, and engaging with confidence. GTD emphasizes clearing your mind by externalizing commitments and using a trusted system.

concepts.name: Inbox Zero
concepts.summary: A methodology for keeping inboxes empty through systematic processing.
concepts.explanation: Inbox Zero is a processing methodology for clearing and decision-making on incoming items. The goal is to avoid feeling overwhelmed by systematically processing items before they accumulate. This principle applies not just to email but to any inbox - including fleeting notes, task lists, and capture systems. The key is to make decisions about each item: delete it, delegate it, respond to it, defer it, or do it. Regular processing prevents the inbox from becoming a source of stress and ensures nothing falls through the cracks.

concepts.name: Progressive Summarization
concepts.summary: A layered highlighting method to distill information over time.
concepts.explanation: Progressive Summarization is Tiago Forte's layered highlighting method for distilling information. Instead of trying to summarize everything at once, you progressively add layers of highlighting as you revisit content: Layer 1 is the original notes, Layer 2 is bold highlighting of key passages, Layer 3 is highlighted portions of the bold text, Layer 4 is your own executive summary. This approach is really a mindful technique - a practice for fine-tuning intuition and self-awareness. It acknowledges that you don't know which information will be valuable until you need it.

concepts.name: Capture System
concepts.summary: A reliable system for quickly capturing thoughts, ideas, and information.
concepts.explanation: A capture system is your reliable external storage for thoughts, ideas, inspiration, and information. Ideas are fragile - you need a quick way to capture them without friction. You don't want to have to think about where information needs to go or where to look for it. Having a capture system removes that friction. The system should be always accessible, quick to use, and trusted. Capturing should be a habit that doesn't take any energy or decisions. Daily notes often serve as an excellent capture system since they're always available and time-stamped.

articles.title: Streamline Your Note-Taking: Why Daily Notes Should Be Your Capture System

concepts.name: Daily Notes
concepts.summary: Time-stamped notes created each day for journaling and capture.
concepts.explanation: Daily notes are chronological notes created each day that serve multiple purposes: journaling, capturing thoughts and ideas, tracking tasks, and providing context for when things happened. They act as an excellent capture system because they're always available, automatically organized by time, and don't require decisions about where to file information. Daily notes can be the seeds that grow into atomic notes, and connecting your notes with time helps with retrieval and provides historical context. They're the perfect entry point into growing a Knowledge Management practice.

articles.title: How to Structure Your Daily Notes in Obsidian
How I use daily notes

concepts.name: Journaling
concepts.summary: The practice of regularly recording thoughts, experiences, and reflections.
concepts.explanation: Journaling is the practice of regularly writing down thoughts, ideas, experiences, feelings, and reflections. It's the perfect entry point for PKM, helping you expand your ideas and prevent losing important ones you may want to act on. Benefits include self-reflection, idea development, accountability, stress reduction, and better memory. Journaling throughout the day (interstitial journaling) captures context and mental state. For people with ADHD, journaling can be particularly powerful for organizing scattered thoughts. Combined with periodic reviews, journaling creates a comprehensive system for personal growth.

articles.title: Journaling every day is powerful Part 1
Journaling every day is powerful Part 2
Stop Losing Your Best Ideas - The Journaling System That Changed My Life

concepts.name: Periodic Reviews
concepts.summary: Regular reflection sessions to review progress and plan ahead.
concepts.explanation: Periodic reviews are regular system maintenance and reflection sessions - weekly, monthly, quarterly, and yearly. They help track progress, maintain your PKM system, process accumulated notes, and plan ahead. Knowledge rollover through periodic reviews ensures continuity. Reviews should include: processing inboxes, reviewing completed work, updating goals, reflecting on what worked and what didn't, and planning the next period. This practice is awesome for tracking progress and planning ahead, turning your knowledge base into an active tool rather than a passive archive.

articles.title: Periodic Reviews for a Happier and More Productive Life

concepts.name: Connected Notes
concepts.summary: Notes that link to other notes, creating a web of knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Connected notes are notes that link to other related notes, creating a web of interconnected knowledge rather than isolated silos. It's rare for knowledge to live in isolation - that's why connecting ideas is key for PKM. Connections between ideas are as valuable as the ideas themselves, perhaps even more so. The simple act of creating links helps your brain realize that ideas are connected, aiding memorization and recall. Ways to connect notes include direct links, tags, backlinks, and Maps of Content.

articles.title: How to connect ideas

concepts.name: Backlinks
concepts.summary: Automatic links showing all notes that reference a particular note.
concepts.explanation: Backlinks are reverse connections that show all notes linking to a particular note. While regular links point forward to other notes, backlinks reveal what points to the current note, creating bi-directional connections. This feature is fundamental to tools like Obsidian and Roam Research. Backlinks help discover unexpected connections, understand context, and navigate your knowledge base in multiple directions. They make your knowledge graph more navigable and help surface relationships you might not have explicitly created.

concepts.name: Tagging
concepts.summary: Adding keywords or labels to notes for categorization and retrieval.
concepts.explanation: Tagging is the practice of adding keywords or labels to notes for categorization and easier retrieval. Tags are no better or worse than folders, links, or MOCs - they're complementary. When you tag information, don't look for the one perfect tag. Instead, add as many relevant keywords as you can - those are pathways to stumble upon notes later. Tags and metadata enable finding information when you need it, maximizing usefulness and leverage. Each tag you add creates a path to resurface that note in the future.

articles.title: Why and How to Tag Your Notes

concepts.name: Templates
concepts.summary: Pre-defined structures that standardize note creation and boost consistency.
concepts.explanation: Templates are pre-defined note structures that standardize note creation and boost consistency. They're beneficial for note-taking and PKM because they shift focus from how to capture information to the information itself, leading to clearer thoughts and more effective learning. Templates can evolve over time as needs change. They make notes easier to find (consistent structure aids search), increase productivity (less thinking about format), and ensure important elements aren't forgotten. The Obsidian Starter Kit includes many templates for different note types.

articles.title: Unlocking Efficiency and Consistency in Note-Taking: The Power of Templates

concepts.name: Obsidian
concepts.summary: A powerful note-taking app that uses local Markdown files and linking.
concepts.explanation: Obsidian is a powerful tool for thought that uses local Markdown files, emphasizes linking between notes, and includes a graph view to visualize connections. Benefits include: local-first (you own your data), Markdown-based (future-proof and portable), extensive plugin ecosystem, graph visualization, Canvas for visual thinking, and strong community. Obsidian serves as a thinking headquarters - a fourth place beyond home, work, and social spaces where thoughts can exist, be developed, and grow. It's all you need from simple notes to complete productivity.

articles.title: Why Obsidian is All You Need - From Simple Notes to Complete Productivity
How I synchronize and backup my Obsidian notes

concepts.name: Markdown
concepts.summary: A lightweight markup language for creating formatted text.
concepts.explanation: Markdown is a lightweight markup language for creating formatted text using plain text syntax. Created by John Gruber, it's widely used for documentation, notes, and content creation. Benefits include: human-readable in raw form, convertible to HTML and other formats, supported by most note-taking apps, future-proof (just text files), and portable. Markdown supports headers, lists, links, images, code blocks, and more. The file-over-app principle recommends using formats like Markdown that you control and that will outlast any specific application.

articles.title: Markdown introduction

concepts.name: Tools for Thought
concepts.summary: Software designed to enhance thinking, learning, and knowledge work.
concepts.explanation: Tools for Thought (TfTs) are software applications designed to augment human thinking, learning, and knowledge work. They go beyond simple note-taking to help you think, connect ideas, and develop knowledge. Must-have features include: linking between notes, search functionality, Markdown support, local storage. Nice-to-have features include: graph visualization, backlinks, daily notes, templates, plugins. When choosing a tool, focus on the mindset and methods more than on tools - a Tool for Thought is NOT a PKM System in and of itself. There's a process around it.

concepts.name: Digital Garden
concepts.summary: A publicly shared collection of evolving notes and ideas.
concepts.explanation: A digital garden is a publicly shared collection of notes and ideas that grow and evolve over time, unlike traditional blogs with polished, finished posts. Like a real garden, content is planted (created), nurtured (revised), and sometimes removed. Digital gardens embrace imperfection and show work-in-progress thinking. Your PKM system is a garden - daily notes are the seeds, atomic notes are the plants, and your knowledge base is the flourishing ecosystem. Nurture it daily.

concepts.name: Knowledge Management
concepts.summary: The process of creating, sharing, using, and managing knowledge in organizations.
concepts.explanation: Knowledge Management (KM) is the process of creating, sharing, using, and managing knowledge and information in an organization or for an individual. The secret of Knowledge Management is understanding that it's, first and foremost, a practice that needs to be fully integrated in your life and work before you can reap the benefits. KM isn't a separate activity - it should be part of everything you do. It isn't about adding more work to your day; it's about transforming how you handle the work you already do. KM goes way beyond productivity - it's a means to learn more about yourself, develop your potential, and live the life you were meant to live.

articles.title: 10 Essential Knowledge Management Methods Every Professional Should Master
The Hidden Cost of Ignoring Knowledge Management

concepts.name: Information Management
concepts.summary: The collection, organization, storage, and retrieval of information.
concepts.explanation: Information Management (IM) is the collection, organization, storage, maintenance, retrieval, and dissemination of information. While related to Knowledge Management, IM focuses more on the handling of data and information, whereas KM emphasizes the transformation of information into actionable knowledge. Both are important but serve different purposes. Information is just data; knowledge is how you use the data. Not all information is knowledge, but all knowledge is information.

concepts.name: DIKW Pyramid
concepts.summary: Data, Information, Knowledge, Wisdom hierarchy.
concepts.explanation: The DIKW Pyramid represents the hierarchy from Data to Information to Knowledge to Wisdom. Data is raw facts and figures; Information is data with context and meaning; Knowledge is information that has been understood, internalized, and can be applied; Wisdom is the ability to make sound judgments based on knowledge and experience. Knowledge Management is one of the enablers to help us go from Information Overwhelm to Wisdom. Understanding this hierarchy helps prioritize what to capture and how to process it.

concepts.name: Collector's Fallacy
concepts.summary: The trap of collecting information without processing or using it.
concepts.explanation: The Collector's Fallacy is the tendency to collect information, resources, and notes without actually processing, understanding, or using them. Just because you can capture everything doesn't mean you should. Hoarding information without purpose leads to feeling overwhelmed and won't help you reach your goals. The challenge is knowing which knowledge is worth acquiring. Be intentional - unless your goal is to have fun, avoid hoarding information without purpose. You Aren't Gonna Read It (YAGRI).

concepts.name: Information Overload
concepts.summary: The state of being overwhelmed by too much information.
concepts.explanation: Information Overload is the state of being overwhelmed by the sheer volume of information available. It's one of the key problems knowledge workers face today. PKM helps address this by providing systems to filter, organize, and process information intentionally. Instead of indiscriminately consuming content and doom scrolling, PKM teaches you to be selective, focusing mainly on information that serves your objectives. Tips for managing information overload include: choosing sources carefully, using the test of time, applying the law of staleness, and being intentional about what you capture.

concepts.name: Single Source of Truth (SSOT)
concepts.summary: The practice of having one authoritative location for each piece of information.
concepts.explanation: Single Source of Truth (SSOT) is the practice of structuring information so that each data element is stored exactly once in one authoritative location. In PKM, this means having one place where you go to save and retrieve knowledge, brain dumps, and ideas. This creates reliability and trust in your system - you always know where to find things. Why centralization matters: it eliminates confusion, reduces duplication, ensures consistency, and builds confidence in your system. Combined with the DRY principle, SSOT helps maintain a clean, efficient knowledge base.

articles.title: Why you need a single source of truth for your PKM

concepts.name: Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY)
concepts.summary: The principle of avoiding information duplication.
concepts.explanation: Don't Repeat Yourself (DRY) is a principle aimed at reducing repetition of information. In knowledge management, it means avoiding duplicating information across multiple notes or locations. However, DRY is a guideline, not an absolute rule - repeating yourself in a knowledge base is sometimes okay. There are different ways to present the same ideas, different points of view to explore, many layers of reality and shades of gray. The key is being intentional about duplication rather than letting it happen accidentally.

concepts.name: File Over App
concepts.summary: The principle of preferring file formats you own over proprietary app formats.
concepts.explanation: The File Over App principle advocates for storing information in open, portable file formats (like Markdown, plain text) rather than proprietary formats locked into specific applications. This ensures your data remains accessible regardless of what happens to any particular app - it future-proofs your knowledge. You own files; you merely use apps. Apps come and go, but files can last forever if stored in standard formats. This principle is fundamental to tools like Obsidian that use local Markdown files.

concepts.name: Interstitial Journaling
concepts.summary: Journaling in the gaps between tasks throughout the day.
concepts.explanation: Interstitial Journaling is the practice of capturing thoughts, reflections, and notes in the gaps between tasks throughout your day, rather than only at dedicated journaling times. This approach captures context and mental state in real-time, preserves ideas that might otherwise be lost, helps with task transitions, and provides a more accurate record of your day. It works naturally with daily notes and reduces the pressure of needing a dedicated journaling session.

concepts.name: Morning Pages
concepts.summary: A daily morning practice of stream-of-consciousness writing.
concepts.explanation: Morning Pages is a daily practice of writing three pages of stream-of-consciousness text first thing in the morning. Introduced by Julia Cameron in 'The Artist's Way', it's designed to clear mental clutter, unlock creativity, and process thoughts before starting the day. There's no wrong way to do morning pages - you write whatever comes to mind without editing or judgment. The practice helps silence your inner critic and can reveal insights that might not surface through structured thinking.

references.title: The Artist's Way Morning Pages Journal

concepts.name: Brain Dumps
concepts.summary: The practice of quickly emptying your mind onto paper or screen.
concepts.explanation: Brain dumps are the practice of quickly getting everything out of your head and onto paper or screen without organizing or filtering. When feeling overwhelmed, a brain dump helps clear mental clutter, reduce cognitive load, and externalize thoughts so they can be processed systematically. By externalizing thoughts, you clear mental space for creativity and innovation. Brain dumps can be part of daily journaling, weekly reviews, or done whenever needed to regain clarity.

concepts.name: Knowledge Ingestion
concepts.summary: The systematic process of absorbing and integrating new knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Knowledge Ingestion is the systematic process of absorbing, processing, and integrating new information into your knowledge base. It involves capturing information from various sources, processing it (summarizing, highlighting, annotating), distilling key insights, connecting to existing knowledge, and storing appropriately. The process transforms raw information into usable knowledge. It's the workflow from consumption to capture to integration.

articles.title: Transform Information Chaos Into Knowledge Power: A Simple 10-Step Process
The Knowledge Funnel - From Capture to Connected Notes

concepts.name: Feynman Technique
concepts.summary: A learning method based on explaining concepts in simple terms.
concepts.explanation: The Feynman Technique is a learning method named after physicist Richard Feynman that involves explaining concepts in simple terms as if teaching a child. The four steps are: 1) Choose a concept, 2) Explain it in simple language, 3) Identify gaps in your understanding, 4) Review and simplify further. If you can't explain something simply, you don't understand it well enough. Writing about a topic helps uncover gaps in understanding. This technique is powerful for deepening comprehension and revealing what you truly know.

articles.title: The Feynman Technique

concepts.name: Spaced Repetition
concepts.summary: A learning technique that reviews information at increasing intervals.
concepts.explanation: Spaced Repetition is a learning technique where review sessions are spaced out at increasing intervals over time. Based on the forgetting curve discovered by Hermann Ebbinghaus, it optimizes the timing of reviews to maximize retention with minimal effort. Information is reviewed just as you're about to forget it, strengthening memory each time. Tools like Anki implement this algorithmically. Combined with active recall, spaced repetition is one of the most effective learning strategies available.

concepts.name: Forgetting Curve
concepts.summary: The exponential decay of memory retention over time.
concepts.explanation: The Forgetting Curve, discovered by Hermann Ebbinghaus, describes how memory retention declines exponentially over time without reinforcement. Within 24 hours, you forget about 70% of new information; within a week, up to 90%. However, each review 'resets' and strengthens the memory, flattening the curve. This is why PKM is valuable - by externalizing knowledge, you don't need to rely on imperfect human memory. Your knowledge base becomes reliable external memory that never forgets.

concepts.name: Deep Work
concepts.summary: Focused, distraction-free work on cognitively demanding tasks.
concepts.explanation: Deep Work, a concept popularized by Cal Newport, refers to focused, distraction-free work on cognitively demanding tasks that push your cognitive capabilities. It's the opposite of shallow work (logistical tasks, email, meetings). Deep work produces rare and valuable results and is increasingly important in the knowledge economy. Strategies include: time blocking, eliminating distractions, building deep work rituals, and embracing boredom. PKM supports deep work by externalizing information so you can focus on thinking rather than remembering.

concepts.name: Flow State
concepts.summary: A mental state of complete immersion and focus in an activity.
concepts.explanation: Flow, described by psychologist Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi, is a mental state of complete immersion, focus, and enjoyment in an activity. Characteristics include: intense concentration, merging of action and awareness, loss of self-consciousness, sense of control, distorted time perception, and intrinsic motivation. Flow occurs when challenge level matches skill level. Tips to get more often in the zone include: eliminating distractions, setting clear goals, getting immediate feedback, and working on appropriately challenging tasks.

concepts.name: Context Switching
concepts.summary: The mental cost of shifting between tasks or projects.
concepts.explanation: Context switching is the cognitive cost of shifting attention between different tasks, projects, or mental contexts. Each switch requires time to reload relevant information, refocus attention, and get back into flow. Research suggests it can take 15-25 minutes to fully resume a complex task after an interruption. This is why multitasking is largely an illusion - you're actually rapid-switching, losing efficiency each time. Saving and restoring mental contexts can help reduce this overhead.

articles.title: Saving and restoring mental contexts to improve mental health and productivity

concepts.name: Time Blocking
concepts.summary: Scheduling specific blocks of time for different tasks or activities.
concepts.explanation: Time blocking is a time management method where you divide your day into blocks of time, each dedicated to a specific task or type of work. Instead of working from a to-do list and switching as needed, you assign tasks to specific time slots. Benefits include: reduced context switching, clearer priorities, better focus, and more realistic planning. Variations include day theming (dedicating entire days to types of work) and task batching (grouping similar tasks together).

concepts.name: Pomodoro Technique
concepts.summary: A time management method using focused work intervals with breaks.
concepts.explanation: The Pomodoro Technique, developed by Francesco Cirillo, is a time management method using 25-minute focused work intervals (pomodoros) separated by 5-minute breaks, with longer breaks after every four pomodoros. The technique helps maintain focus, prevent burnout, and make work more measurable. The timer creates urgency and commitment. Knowing a break is coming makes it easier to resist distractions. The technique is named after the tomato-shaped kitchen timer Cirillo used as a student.

concepts.name: Eisenhower Matrix
concepts.summary: A prioritization framework using urgency and importance dimensions.
concepts.explanation: The Eisenhower Matrix (also called Urgent-Important Matrix) is a prioritization framework dividing tasks into four quadrants based on urgency and importance: 1) Urgent & Important (Do first), 2) Important but Not Urgent (Schedule), 3) Urgent but Not Important (Delegate), 4) Neither (Eliminate). Named after President Eisenhower who was known for exceptional productivity, it helps focus on what truly matters rather than just what's pressing. Most deep work falls into quadrant 2.

concepts.name: Systems Thinking
concepts.summary: Understanding how components interact within larger systems.
concepts.explanation: Systems thinking is an approach to understanding how components interact within larger systems, focusing on relationships and patterns rather than isolated parts. It recognizes that the whole is more than the sum of its parts, and that changes in one area affect others. In PKM, systems thinking helps you design better knowledge systems, understand how different practices interact, and see the bigger picture. Focus on the system as a whole, not on each individual idea.

concepts.name: First Principles Thinking
concepts.summary: Breaking down problems to fundamental truths and building up from there.
concepts.explanation: First Principles thinking is a problem-solving approach that breaks down complex problems to their most fundamental truths, then builds up from there. Instead of reasoning by analogy (what others do), you identify the core elements and construct new solutions. This approach, famously used by Elon Musk, helps escape conventional thinking and find innovative solutions. By starting from first principles, creating atomic notes, and thinking in systems, you can combine ideas to form more complex ones.

concepts.name: Mental Models
concepts.summary: Frameworks for understanding how things work in the world.
concepts.explanation: Mental models are frameworks, concepts, and worldviews that help you understand how things work and make better decisions. Examples include: Pareto Principle (80/20 rule), Inversion (thinking backwards), Occam's Razor (simpler explanations are better), and Circle of Competence. Learn and memorize first principles and mental models - they're the building blocks of clear thinking. Knowledge is emergent - it lies in the connections we make between ideas, which is why mental models are so useful to develop and acquire.

concepts.name: Readwise
concepts.summary: A service for capturing and reviewing highlights from various sources.
concepts.explanation: Readwise is a service that aggregates highlights from various sources (Kindle, web articles, PDFs, podcasts) and helps you review them using spaced repetition. It can sync highlights to note-taking apps like Obsidian through the official Readwise plugin. This makes it an excellent content curation solution for capturing literature notes and building your knowledge base from what you read across different platforms.

concepts.name: Obsidian Web Clipper

concepts.explanation: The Obsidian Web Clipper is a browser extension that allows you to capture web content directly into your Obsidian vault. It can extract article content, preserve formatting, add metadata, and use templates for consistent capture. This makes it a powerful content curation solution for building your knowledge base from web sources. It significantly reduces the friction of capturing information from the web.

articles.title: Supercharge Your PKM Workflow with the Obsidian Web Clipper

concepts.name: PKM System
concepts.summary: A complete personal knowledge management system combining tools, processes, and practices.
concepts.explanation: A PKM System (PKMS) is a complete personal knowledge management system that combines tools, processes, and practices for managing personal information and knowledge. Elements include: capture mechanisms, organization structure, note types, linking practices, review processes, and output workflows. The right way to think about a PKM system is as an integral part of everything you do. It should be one you can actually trust with important memories, ideas, insights, information, knowledge, and wisdom.

articles.title: The Complete Knowledge Management System Checklist

concepts.name: Note-taking vs Note-making
concepts.summary: The distinction between capturing external information and creating your own knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Note-taking is about capturing information from the outside world - lectures, books, articles, conversations. Note-making is about expressing yourself - your thoughts, ideas, interpretations, and creations. Both are complementary and valuable. Note-taking is all about capturing information, while note-making is about expressing ourselves. When you are learning, note-taking helps capture what matters. When you are expressing yourself, note-making is the way. Understanding this distinction helps you approach each appropriately.

articles.title: Tips to get started with note-taking

concepts.name: Smart Notes
concepts.summary: Notes designed for reuse, connection, and long-term value.
concepts.explanation: Smart notes are notes designed to be reusable, well-connected, and provide long-term value - as opposed to 'dumb notes' that are written once and never revisited. Smart notes are building blocks - created once, used forever. They follow principles like atomicity, clear writing, proper linking, and standalone comprehensibility. Reusing previous notes and connecting those with other ones is a key aspect of creating smart notes. The concept is central to the How to Take Smart Notes methodology by SÃ¶nke Ahrens.

articles.title: How to capture book notes and turn those into smart notes

concepts.name: Fourth Place
concepts.summary: A thinking space beyond work, home, and social spaces.
concepts.explanation: The Fourth Place is a concept describing the need for a thinking space beyond our traditional three places: home (first place), work (second place), and social spaces (third place). We need a fourth place where our thoughts can exist outside our heads, where we can interact with them, play with them, and develop them into something greater. Your PKM system serves as this fourth place - a thinking headquarters. Obsidian is my Fourth Place and Command Center.

articles.title: You need a Fourth Place - A place to think

concepts.name: Mind Maps
concepts.summary: Visual diagrams for organizing information hierarchically from a central topic.
concepts.explanation: Mind Maps are radial visual diagrams for organizing information hierarchically, starting from a central topic and branching out with related ideas. Created by Tony Buzan, they leverage visual thinking and the brain's natural tendency for association. Mind maps are useful for brainstorming, note-taking during lectures, project planning, and exploring connections between ideas. They represent radiant thinking - the non-linear thinking pattern that radiates from a central concept through associations in multiple directions.

concepts.name: Writing is Thinking
concepts.summary: The principle that writing clarifies and develops thought.
concepts.explanation: Writing is Thinking captures the idea that writing isn't just recording thoughts - it's the process of developing and clarifying them. How do people even know what they think, if they don't write? If you think without writing, you only think you're thinking. Writing helps channel your thoughts and brings clarity where the mind alone may struggle. Writing is understanding - the act of putting ideas into words forces you to examine them more closely and discover what you actually know.

articles.title: On The Importance Of Writing

concepts.name: Active Reading
concepts.summary: Engaged reading with note-taking, questioning, and reflection.
concepts.explanation: Active Reading is an engaged approach to reading that involves taking notes, asking questions, making connections, and reflecting rather than passively consuming text. The goal is not to read faster and go through as many books as you can, but rather to retain more of what you read. You read slower but get a lot more out of it. When you only read, you're missing 90% of the benefits. Truly learning requires thinking, and thinking requires writing.

articles.title: Why you should take notes while reading non-fiction books
The Art of Reading Slowly

concepts.name: Lindy Effect
concepts.summary: The idea that the longer something has survived, the longer it's likely to survive.
concepts.explanation: The Lindy Effect suggests that for non-perishable things (ideas, technologies, books), the longer they have survived, the longer they're likely to continue surviving. A book that has been in print for 100 years is likely to remain in print for another 100 years. This is useful for choosing what to learn - focus on memorizing timeless information and classic works rather than chasing trends. Ideas that have stood the test of time are more likely to remain valuable.

concepts.name: Cognitive Load
concepts.summary: The mental effort required for processing and storing information.
concepts.explanation: Cognitive load refers to the amount of mental effort and working memory being used for information processing. When cognitive load is too high, learning and performance suffer. PKM helps manage cognitive load by externalizing information - we need to externalize our thinking to feel less overwhelmed and think more deeply. Your brain is for having ideas, not holding them. By using external systems to store information, you free up mental resources for creative thinking and problem-solving.

concepts.name: Concept Maps
concepts.summary: Visual diagrams showing relationships between concepts.
concepts.explanation: Concept Maps are visual diagrams that show relationships between concepts using nodes (concepts) and labeled links (relationships). Unlike mind maps which are hierarchical, concept maps are network-based and show cross-links between different branches. They're powerful for understanding complex topics, identifying gaps in knowledge, and visualizing how concepts relate to each other. This mirrors how knowledge exists as a network of interconnected ideas.

concepts.name: Visual Thinking
concepts.summary: Using visual representations to understand and organize information.
concepts.explanation: Visual thinking is the practice of using visual representations to understand, organize, communicate, and solve problems. It leverages the brain's powerful visual processing capabilities. Tools include mind maps, concept maps, diagrams, sketches, and canvas tools. Dual Coding Theory explains how human cognition processes verbal and visual information through separate but interconnected systems, making visual thinking a powerful complement to text-based notes.

concepts.name: Top of Mind Note
concepts.summary: A note tracking current priorities, projects, and focus areas.
concepts.explanation: A Top of Mind Note is a special note that tracks your current priorities, active projects, key questions, and focus areas. It serves as a dashboard showing what's most important right now and what deserves your attention. This note is reviewed and updated regularly, helping maintain clarity on priorities amid the noise of daily work. It's a practical implementation of keeping important things visible and not buried in your system.

concepts.name: 12 Favorite Questions
concepts.summary: A framework of guiding questions to drive curiosity and learning.
concepts.explanation: The 12 Favorite Questions technique, inspired by physicist Richard Feynman, involves maintaining a list of your most important open questions. When you encounter new information, you check whether it helps answer any of your questions. This creates a filter for what to capture and a framework for connecting new knowledge to your interests. The questions evolve over time as some get answered and new ones emerge.

It incorporates best practices from Zettelkasten, PARA, Johnny Decimal, and other methodologies.
