concepts.name: PKM Coaching
concepts.summary: One-on-one personalized guidance for implementing effective knowledge management.
concepts.explanation: Personal Knowledge Management Coaching provides one-on-one personalized guidance to implement effective Knowledge Management strategies, overcome challenges, and optimize your workflow. Perfect for newcomers needing structured guidance, experienced users wanting to refine their system, or anyone facing specific PKM challenges. Sessions with SÃ©bastien Dubois help you design, implement, and iterate on your personal knowledge management practice.

concepts.name: Open Loops
concepts.summary: Incomplete tasks and unresolved commitments that occupy mental space.
concepts.explanation: Open loops refer to incomplete tasks, unresolved problems, unexplored ideas, or any form of unprocessed information that requires attention or action. First discussed in David Allen's Getting Things Done (GTD) methodology, these are essentially anything that pulls at our attention, signaling that something needs to be acted upon, finished, or decided. Each open loop requires cognitive resources, creating background noise that constantly demands attention. This leads to cognitive overload where the brain's capacity to process information is surpassed. Closing open loops liberates cognitive resources, reducing stress and enhancing mental clarity.

concepts.name: ABCDE Method
concepts.summary: A prioritization system categorizing tasks by importance and action type.
concepts.explanation: The ABCDE method is a prioritization and task management system where tasks are categorized as: A, B, or C for high, medium, or low priority respectively; D for delegate; and E for eliminate. This simple framework helps quickly triage tasks and focus on what truly matters. By explicitly identifying tasks to delegate or eliminate, you reduce cognitive load and ensure important work gets done first.

concepts.name: Six Thinking Hats
concepts.summary: A parallel thinking method using different colored hats to represent thinking modes.
concepts.explanation: The Six Thinking Hats is a parallel thinking method developed by Edward de Bono in 1985 that structures thinking and discussion by having participants adopt different thinking modes represented by colored hats. White Hat (facts), Red Hat (emotions), Black Hat (critical judgment), Yellow Hat (positive benefits), Green Hat (creativity), and Blue Hat (process control). Instead of everyone thinking in different directions simultaneously, all participants 'wear' the same hat at the same time, focusing collectively on one type of thinking before moving to the next. This reduces conflict, improves decision quality, and makes discussions more productive.

references.title: Six Thinking Hats by Edward de Bono

concepts.name: SCALE Method
concepts.summary: A framework for leveraging AI through systematic capture, connection, and growth.
concepts.explanation: The SCALE method is an acronym for leveraging AI effectively: Systematic capture (document every AI interaction), Connected knowledge (link prompts to contexts and results), Active processing (weekly review and pattern extraction), Leveraged learning (turn interactions into reusable assets), and Exponential growth (compound improvements over time). Core principles include: every prompt is an asset, every interaction builds, every pattern scales, every system grows, and every result compounds.

concepts.name: 5 Minute Journal
concepts.summary: A quick daily reflection format for building journaling habits.
concepts.explanation: The 5 Minute Journal is a structured, quick daily reflection format designed to build journaling habits with minimal time investment. It typically includes morning prompts (gratitude, daily goals, affirmations) and evening prompts (highlights, lessons learned). The simplicity and brevity make it accessible for beginners and sustainable long-term. It's an effective entry point into journaling practices.

concepts.name: Habit Stacking
concepts.summary: Linking new habits to existing ones to leverage established neural pathways.
concepts.explanation: Habit Stacking, popularized by James Clear in Atomic Habits, is the practice of linking a new habit to an existing one to leverage established neural pathways and create natural triggers. The formula is: 'After I [CURRENT HABIT], I will [NEW HABIT].' By attaching new behaviors to existing routines, you reduce the friction of habit formation. This technique is particularly useful for integrating PKM practices into daily life.

concepts.name: Dual Coding Theory
concepts.summary: The theory that cognition processes verbal and visual information through separate systems.
concepts.explanation: Dual Coding Theory explains how human cognition processes verbal and visual information through separate but interconnected systems. When information is encoded both verbally and visually, it creates stronger memory traces and improves recall. This is why visual thinking, mind maps, and combining text with images are powerful learning strategies. The theory supports using multiple modalities in note-taking and knowledge management.

concepts.name: Metacognition
concepts.summary: Thinking about thinking - awareness and understanding of one's own thought processes.
concepts.explanation: Metacognition is thinking about thinking - the awareness and understanding of one's own thought processes. It involves monitoring your comprehension, recognizing when you don't understand something, and knowing which strategies help you learn best. Metacognitive skills are essential for effective learning and PKM. They help you choose appropriate note-taking strategies, identify knowledge gaps, and optimize your learning process.

concepts.name: Active Recall
concepts.summary: Retrieving information from memory as a learning technique.
concepts.explanation: Active Recall is the practice of actively retrieving information from memory rather than passively reviewing it. Instead of re-reading notes, you test yourself on the material. This retrieval process strengthens memory traces and improves long-term retention. Combined with spaced repetition, active recall is one of the most effective learning strategies. Tools like flashcards and the Feynman Technique leverage active recall.

concepts.name: Elaboration
concepts.summary: Processing information deeply by connecting it to existing knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Elaboration is the learning technique of processing information deeply by connecting it to existing knowledge, explaining it in your own words, and expanding upon it with examples and applications. Rather than surface-level memorization, elaboration creates rich, meaningful connections that improve understanding and retention. This is why writing notes in your own words is more effective than copying verbatim.

concepts.name: Interleaving
concepts.summary: Mixing different topics or problem types during study sessions.
concepts.explanation: Interleaving is the practice of mixing different topics, subjects, or problem types during study sessions rather than focusing on one thing at a time (blocking). While it feels harder in the moment, interleaving improves long-term learning and the ability to transfer knowledge to new situations. It forces your brain to continually retrieve different strategies, strengthening discrimination and flexible application of knowledge.

concepts.name: Growth Mindset
concepts.summary: The belief that abilities can be developed through effort and learning.
concepts.explanation: Growth Mindset, developed by psychologist Carol Dweck, is the belief that abilities and intelligence can be developed through dedication, hard work, and learning. This contrasts with a fixed mindset that views abilities as innate and unchangeable. People with a growth mindset embrace challenges, persist through obstacles, see effort as the path to mastery, learn from criticism, and find inspiration in others' success. This mindset is foundational for effective learning and PKM.

concepts.name: Intrinsic Motivation
concepts.summary: Internal drive from enjoyment and satisfaction rather than external rewards.
concepts.explanation: Intrinsic motivation is the internal drive that comes from enjoyment, curiosity, satisfaction, and personal engagement rather than external rewards like money or recognition. Activities driven by intrinsic motivation are sustainable and fulfilling. For PKM to be effective long-term, it should tap into intrinsic motivation - genuine curiosity, the joy of learning, and the satisfaction of creating connections. Understanding your intrinsic motivators helps design systems you'll actually use.

concepts.name: Extrinsic Motivation
concepts.summary: Motivation driven by external factors like rewards, pressure, and consequences.
concepts.explanation: Extrinsic motivation is driven by external factors such as rewards, recognition, deadlines, or avoiding negative consequences. While useful for some tasks, over-reliance on extrinsic motivation can undermine intrinsic interest and creativity. Understanding the balance between intrinsic and extrinsic motivation helps design effective personal systems. For PKM, building habits that eventually become intrinsically rewarding leads to sustainable practice.

concepts.name: Dunning-Kruger Effect
concepts.summary: Cognitive bias where novices overestimate and experts underestimate their abilities.
concepts.explanation: The Dunning-Kruger Effect is a cognitive bias in which people with limited competence in a domain overestimate their abilities, while experts tend to underestimate theirs. Beginners lack the knowledge to recognize their limitations, while experts are more aware of what they don't know. This has implications for learning: initial confidence may be misplaced, and feeling less confident as you learn more is actually a sign of growth. PKM helps by making knowledge gaps visible.

concepts.name: Zeigarnik Effect
concepts.summary: The tendency to remember uncompleted tasks better than completed ones.
concepts.explanation: The Zeigarnik Effect is the psychological phenomenon where people remember uncompleted or interrupted tasks better than completed ones. Open loops occupy mental space until resolved. This is why open tasks create cognitive load and why the GTD practice of capturing everything helps - once a task is written down and captured in a trusted system, the mind can let go of holding onto it. Closing loops through completion or capture frees mental resources.

concepts.name: Narrative Fallacy
concepts.summary: The tendency to create overly coherent stories from random or complex events.
concepts.explanation: The Narrative Fallacy is the human tendency to construct coherent stories and explanations from random or complex events, making the world seem more predictable and understandable than it really is. We see patterns where none exist and create causal explanations for coincidences. This bias can lead to overconfidence in predictions and simplified understanding of complex systems. Awareness of this fallacy helps maintain intellectual humility in note-taking and analysis.

concepts.name: Survivorship Bias
concepts.summary: Focusing on successful examples while ignoring failures that didn't survive.
concepts.explanation: Survivorship Bias is the logical error of concentrating on people or things that 'survived' some process while overlooking those that didn't, leading to false conclusions. We study successful companies without considering failed ones, or successful methods without seeing failed approaches. It's easy to see someone's success because of survivorship bias - we don't see the many who tried the same thing and failed. This awareness helps evaluate advice and methods more critically.

concepts.name: Recency Bias
concepts.summary: The tendency to overweight recent information in decision-making.
concepts.explanation: Recency Bias is the tendency to give disproportionate weight to recent events or information when making decisions or predictions. What happened recently feels more relevant and influential than older data, even when it shouldn't be. This can lead to overreacting to recent trends and undervaluing historical patterns. Fighting against recency bias is important for making balanced decisions. PKM systems help by preserving and surfacing older but relevant information.

concepts.name: Novelty Bias
concepts.summary: Disproportionate attraction to new information over established knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Novelty Bias is the tendency to be disproportionately attracted to new information, tools, and methods over established ones. We're drawn to the latest frameworks, newest apps, and freshest ideas, sometimes at the expense of proven approaches. This leads to tool hopping, method switching, and constant restarts. The Lindy Effect suggests established ideas may be more valuable. Being aware of novelty bias helps maintain focus on what works rather than what's new.

concepts.name: Design Thinking
concepts.summary: A user-centered creative problem-solving approach.
concepts.explanation: Design Thinking is a human-centered approach to innovation and problem-solving developed at Stanford's d.school. The process typically includes five phases: Empathize (understand the user), Define (frame the problem), Ideate (generate ideas), Prototype (create solutions), and Test (gather feedback). It emphasizes understanding user needs, challenging assumptions, redefining problems, and creating innovative solutions through iterative prototyping. Design thinking principles can be applied to designing PKM systems.

concepts.name: Brainstorming
concepts.summary: A creative ideation technique generating many ideas by suspending judgment.
concepts.explanation: Brainstorming is a creative technique for generating a large number of ideas by suspending judgment and encouraging free association. Key principles include: defer judgment (no criticism during ideation), encourage wild ideas, build on others' ideas, and go for quantity. The goal is to generate as many ideas as possible before evaluating them. Brainstorming can be individual or group-based. In PKM, brain dumps and freewriting are forms of solo brainstorming.

concepts.name: Lateral Thinking
concepts.summary: Problem-solving from indirect, creative angles rather than direct logical steps.
concepts.explanation: Lateral Thinking, coined by Edward de Bono, is a problem-solving approach that seeks solutions through indirect, creative angles rather than direct, logical steps. While vertical thinking digs deeper in the same hole, lateral thinking digs new holes. Techniques include random entry (starting from random stimuli), provocation (deliberately absurd statements), and challenging assumptions. Lateral thinking complements analytical thinking and is essential for innovation and creative problem-solving.

references.title: Lateral Thinking by Edward de Bono

concepts.name: Divergent Thinking
concepts.summary: Generating multiple possible solutions by exploring many different directions.
concepts.explanation: Divergent Thinking is the cognitive process of generating multiple possible solutions or ideas by exploring many different directions and possibilities. It's the 'thinking outside the box' phase where quantity matters more than quality, and judgment is suspended. Divergent thinking is essential for creativity and innovation. It's typically followed by convergent thinking to evaluate and select the best ideas. Both modes are necessary for effective problem-solving.

concepts.name: Convergent Thinking
concepts.summary: Narrowing multiple possibilities to find the single best solution.
concepts.explanation: Convergent Thinking is the cognitive process of narrowing down multiple possibilities to find the single best solution through logical evaluation and analysis. It's the 'focusing in' phase where you apply criteria, make judgments, and select from options generated during divergent thinking. Convergent thinking is analytical and systematic. Effective problem-solving requires balancing divergent exploration with convergent evaluation.

concepts.name: Analytical Thinking
concepts.summary: Systematic process of breaking down complex problems into components.
concepts.explanation: Analytical Thinking is a systematic process of breaking down complex problems into smaller, manageable components, examining relationships between parts, and drawing logical conclusions. It involves gathering data, identifying patterns, evaluating evidence, and constructing reasoned arguments. Analytical thinking is essential for understanding complex systems, troubleshooting problems, and making informed decisions. It complements creative thinking in a complete problem-solving toolkit.

concepts.name: Critical Thinking
concepts.summary: Disciplined analysis and evaluation of information to form well-reasoned judgments.
concepts.explanation: Critical Thinking is the disciplined process of analyzing, evaluating, and synthesizing information to form well-reasoned judgments. It involves questioning assumptions, recognizing biases and fallacies, considering alternative perspectives, and evaluating evidence quality. Critical thinking skills help separate reliable information from misinformation, make better decisions, and avoid cognitive traps. For PKM, critical thinking is essential when capturing and connecting information.

concepts.name: Compound Growth
concepts.summary: Exponential growth where returns generate additional returns over time.
concepts.explanation: Compound Growth is the phenomenon where growth generates additional growth, creating exponential rather than linear progress over time. In finance, compound interest multiplies wealth; in knowledge, compound learning accelerates understanding. Your PKM system creates compounding value - each note and connection makes future learning easier, each insight enables new insights. This is why consistent, incremental progress over time produces remarkable results. PKM is a long-term investment that compounds.

concepts.name: Pareto Principle
concepts.summary: 80% of effects come from 20% of causes - focus on high-impact activities.
concepts.explanation: The Pareto Principle, also known as the 80/20 rule, states that roughly 80% of effects come from 20% of causes. A small portion of inputs typically produces the majority of outputs. In productivity, 20% of your efforts likely produce 80% of your results. In PKM, a small percentage of your notes may provide most of your value. This principle helps prioritize: identify and focus on the vital few rather than the trivial many. Don't try to capture everything - focus on what matters most.

concepts.name: Learning Curve
concepts.summary: The rate of improvement in performing a task as experience accumulates.
concepts.explanation: The Learning Curve represents how proficiency increases with experience over time. Initially, progress is often slow as fundamentals are mastered, then accelerates during the 'steep' part of the curve, and eventually plateaus as mastery is approached. Understanding learning curves helps set realistic expectations - early struggle is normal and doesn't indicate inability. PKM accelerates learning curves by preserving insights and enabling faster retrieval of relevant knowledge.

concepts.name: Broken Windows Theory
concepts.summary: Small signs of disorder lead to more disorder if not addressed.
concepts.explanation: Broken Windows Theory suggests that visible signs of disorder and neglect (like broken windows) encourage further disorder and more serious problems. In PKM, this means that a messy, disorganized knowledge base tends to become messier over time. Maintaining basic order and addressing small issues promptly prevents degradation. However, don't let perfectionism prevent you from using your system - some messiness is acceptable. Balance maintenance with actual use.

concepts.name: Boy Scout Rule
concepts.summary: Leave things better than you found them.
concepts.explanation: The Boy Scout Rule states: 'Leave the campground cleaner than you found it.' Applied to knowledge work and PKM, this means making small improvements whenever you encounter something - fix a typo, add a link, clarify a note, organize a folder. Over time, these small improvements compound. You don't need dedicated maintenance sessions if you consistently make things a little better during regular use. This incremental approach keeps systems healthy without feeling burdensome.

concepts.name: Mise-en-place
concepts.summary: Everything in its place - preparation before action.
concepts.explanation: Mise-en-place (French for 'putting in place') is the culinary practice of organizing and arranging all ingredients and tools before cooking begins. Applied to knowledge work, it means preparing your environment, having tools ready, and organizing information before diving into a task. Staging your environment beforehand reduces the number of decisions you need to make and minimizes friction during execution. This principle supports deep work and flow.

concepts.name: Chunking
concepts.summary: Grouping information into meaningful units to enhance memory and comprehension.
concepts.explanation: Chunking is the cognitive process of grouping individual pieces of information into larger, meaningful units (chunks) to enhance memory and comprehension. Phone numbers are chunked into groups of digits; complex skills are chunked into component sub-skills. In PKM, chunking helps organize information - grouping related notes, creating hierarchies, and building conceptual frameworks. Atomic notes can be chunked together through links and MoCs to form larger understanding.

concepts.name: Two-Minute Rule
concepts.summary: If a task takes less than two minutes, do it immediately.
concepts.explanation: The Two-Minute Rule from GTD states that if a task takes less than two minutes to complete, do it immediately rather than adding it to a list. The overhead of tracking small tasks exceeds the effort of just doing them. This prevents tiny tasks from accumulating and cluttering your systems. For PKM, quickly fixing typos, adding links, or making small edits falls into this category - just do it now rather than creating a task to do it later.

concepts.name: Knowledge Workers
concepts.summary: Professionals whose primary work involves creating, processing, and using information.
concepts.explanation: Knowledge Workers are professionals whose primary work involves creating, processing, and applying information and knowledge rather than physical labor. The term was coined by Peter Drucker. Knowledge workers include developers, writers, researchers, analysts, consultants, designers, and many other professionals. They face unique challenges: information overload, cognitive load, context switching, and the need to continuously learn. PKM is especially valuable for knowledge workers as their productivity depends on effective knowledge management.

concepts.name: LifeOS
concepts.summary: A command center for managing all aspects of your life.
concepts.explanation: LifeOS (Life Operating System) is a concept of using your PKM system as a comprehensive command center for managing all aspects of life - goals, projects, plans, tasks, priorities, health, relationships, finances, and more. It combines strategic (long-term vision) and tactical (daily actions) perspectives. A LifeOS provides focus, tracking, and accountability. It's about seeing your knowledge base not just as an archive but as an active tool for living intentionally and achieving your goals.

concepts.name: Kanban
concepts.summary: A visual workflow management method using boards and cards.
concepts.explanation: Kanban is a visual workflow management method that uses boards with columns representing stages (e.g., To Do, In Progress, Done) and cards representing tasks. Originally developed for manufacturing, it's now widely used for personal productivity and project management. Kanban provides visual clarity on work status, limits work in progress, and helps identify bottlenecks. Many PKM tools including Obsidian support Kanban boards for task and project management.

concepts.name: MoSCoW Method
concepts.summary: Prioritization framework using Must have, Should have, Could have, Won't have.
concepts.explanation: The MoSCoW Method is a prioritization technique that categorizes requirements or tasks into four groups: Must have (essential, non-negotiable), Should have (important but not critical), Could have (nice to have, include if possible), and Won't have (explicitly out of scope for now). This framework helps make difficult prioritization decisions by forcing explicit trade-offs. It's useful for projects, daily planning, and deciding what to capture in your PKM system.

articles.title: Applying the MoSCoW prioritization method to Daily Todos

concepts.name: SWOT Analysis
concepts.summary: Strategic framework analyzing Strengths, Weaknesses, Opportunities, and Threats.
concepts.explanation: SWOT Analysis is a strategic planning framework that evaluates Strengths (internal positives), Weaknesses (internal negatives), Opportunities (external positives), and Threats (external negatives). It provides a structured way to assess situations, make decisions, and develop strategies. SWOT can be applied to personal planning, career decisions, project evaluation, and understanding competitive landscapes. It's a simple but powerful tool for systematic analysis.

concepts.name: Test of Time
concepts.summary: Using longevity as an indicator of information quality and value.
concepts.explanation: The Test of Time is the principle of using longevity as a quality indicator for information and ideas. Content that has remained relevant and valuable over years or decades is more likely to continue being valuable (see Lindy Effect). When curating sources and deciding what to capture, favor ideas that have proven their worth over time rather than chasing the latest trends. Classic books, established principles, and time-tested methods often provide more lasting value.

concepts.name: Law of Staleness
concepts.summary: Fresh information requires more scrutiny as it hasn't been validated over time.
concepts.explanation: The Law of Staleness suggests that fresh, recent information should be viewed with more skepticism because it hasn't been tested and validated over time. New ideas may be exciting but unproven; trends may be temporary fads. While staying current has value, be wary of giving too much weight to the latest thing. Balance consuming new information with revisiting and building on established knowledge. This counters novelty bias.

concepts.name: Garbage In, Garbage Out
concepts.summary: The quality of output depends on the quality of input.
concepts.explanation: Garbage In, Garbage Out (GIGO) is the principle that the quality of output is determined by the quality of input. If you consume low-quality information, your knowledge base and thinking will suffer. If you capture without filtering, your system becomes cluttered with noise. This principle emphasizes the importance of careful curation - selecting high-quality sources, filtering what you consume, and being intentional about what enters your PKM system. Quality over quantity.

concepts.name: Antilibrary
concepts.summary: A collection of unread books representing knowledge yet to be acquired.
concepts.explanation: The Antilibrary, a concept popularized by Nassim Taleb, is the collection of books you own but haven't read. Rather than a sign of failure, an antilibrary represents the humbling reminder of how much you don't know - the knowledge you could potentially acquire. The value of unread books is in their potential. Similarly, a PKM system can include references to resources you haven't fully consumed yet, representing learning opportunities rather than backlogs to feel guilty about.

concepts.name: Focus
concepts.summary: The ability to direct and maintain attention on what matters.
concepts.explanation: Focus is the ability to direct and sustain attention on a chosen task or subject while filtering out distractions. In the age of information overload and constant interruptions, focus is increasingly valuable and increasingly difficult. Focus enables deep work, flow states, and meaningful progress. PKM systems help focus by externalizing information (so you don't need to hold everything in mind) and by clarifying priorities through techniques like daily notes and top-of-mind notes.

concepts.name: Mindfulness
concepts.summary: Present-moment awareness of thoughts, feelings, and environment without judgment.
concepts.explanation: Mindfulness is the practice of present-moment awareness - paying attention to thoughts, feelings, bodily sensations, and environment without judgment. Mindfulness improves focus, reduces stress, enhances decision-making, and supports emotional regulation. For PKM, mindfulness helps with intentional consumption (rather than mindless scrolling), recognizing what truly resonates, and being present while learning. Mindful note-taking involves fully engaging with content rather than passive capture.

concepts.name: Continuous Improvement
concepts.summary: Ongoing, incremental improvement of processes, systems, and performance.
concepts.explanation: Continuous Improvement (Kaizen in Japanese) is the philosophy and practice of making ongoing, incremental improvements to processes, products, and systems. Rather than seeking dramatic transformation, focus on small, consistent enhancements that compound over time. For PKM, this means regularly refining your system based on what works, updating notes as understanding grows, and iterating on processes. Perfection isn't the goal - steady progress is.

concepts.name: Decision Fatigue
concepts.summary: The deteriorating quality of decisions after making many decisions.
concepts.explanation: Decision Fatigue is the phenomenon where the quality of decisions deteriorates after a long session of decision-making. Each decision depletes a finite pool of mental resources, leading to poorer choices, impulsivity, or decision avoidance later in the day. PKM helps combat decision fatigue by reducing daily decisions through templates, established workflows, consistent conventions, and by capturing decisions so they don't need to be remade. Automate and systematize where possible.

concepts.name: Choice Overload
concepts.summary: When too many options leads to difficulty deciding and reduced satisfaction.
concepts.explanation: Choice Overload (also known as the Paradox of Choice) occurs when having too many options makes decision-making harder rather than easier, often leading to anxiety, paralysis, or reduced satisfaction with the choice made. In PKM, this can manifest as tool hopping (too many tool options), template paralysis, or over-engineering systems. Constraints can be liberating. Sometimes limiting options and committing to a 'good enough' choice enables progress that perfect selection never would.

references.title: The Paradox of Choice by Barry Schwartz

concepts.name: Confirmation Bias
concepts.summary: The tendency to favor information that confirms existing beliefs.
concepts.explanation: Confirmation Bias is the tendency to search for, interpret, favor, and recall information in a way that confirms or supports one's prior beliefs or values. We unconsciously filter for evidence that supports what we already think while dismissing contradictory evidence. This is one of the most pervasive cognitive biases. For PKM, awareness of confirmation bias encourages actively seeking out opposing viewpoints, questioning assumptions, and being open to updating beliefs based on new evidence.

concepts.name: Bullet Journal
concepts.summary: A rapid logging system combining tasks, events, and notes in a structured format.
concepts.explanation: The Bullet Journal (BuJo) method, created by Ryder Carroll, is an analog organization system that combines to-do lists, calendars, and notes using rapid logging with bullets, signifiers, and migration. Key components include: an Index (table of contents), Future Log (long-term planning), Monthly Log (month overview), and Daily Log (daily tasks and notes). The method emphasizes intentionality and mindfulness. While designed for paper, the principles translate to digital systems and inspire many PKM templates.

references.title: The Bullet Journal Method by Ryder Carroll

concepts.name: Gratitude Journal
concepts.summary: A practice of regularly recording things you're grateful for.
concepts.explanation: A Gratitude Journal is the practice of regularly writing down things you're grateful for. Research shows gratitude journaling improves mood, increases happiness, reduces stress, and enhances overall wellbeing. Simple formats include listing 3-5 things you're grateful for each day, either in the morning (setting a positive tone) or evening (reflecting on the day). This practice trains the brain to notice positive aspects of life and counters negativity bias.

concepts.name: Weekly Notes
concepts.summary: Weekly summaries and reviews for reflection and planning.
concepts.explanation: Weekly Notes are periodic notes created each week for review, reflection, and planning. They typically include: reviewing what happened during the week, evaluating progress on goals, identifying lessons learned, processing accumulated items, and planning the week ahead. Weekly notes bridge daily tactical notes and longer-term strategic reviews. They help maintain perspective that's easy to lose in daily work and enable knowledge rollover between periods.

articles.title: How I Use Weekly Notes in Obsidian

concepts.name: Monthly Notes
concepts.summary: Monthly summaries for mid-range reflection and goal tracking.
concepts.explanation: Monthly Notes are periodic notes created each month for mid-range reflection and planning. They provide a broader view than weekly notes, tracking progress on larger goals, identifying trends, and adjusting strategies. Monthly reviews help balance immediate tactical work with strategic objectives. They often include goal reviews, habit tracking summaries, key accomplishments, lessons learned, and plans for the coming month.

concepts.name: Quarterly Notes
concepts.summary: Quarterly reviews for strategic assessment and course correction.
concepts.explanation: Quarterly Notes are periodic notes created every three months for strategic assessment and major course corrections. They sit between monthly tactical reviews and yearly strategic planning. Quarterly reviews often align with OKR (Objectives and Key Results) cycles and provide checkpoints for evaluating progress on significant goals. They're opportunities to make meaningful adjustments without waiting a full year.

concepts.name: Yearly Notes
concepts.summary: Annual reviews for big-picture reflection and long-term planning.
concepts.explanation: Yearly Notes are comprehensive annual reviews for big-picture reflection and long-term planning. They involve reviewing the entire year's achievements, failures, and lessons; assessing progress on major life goals; and setting intentions for the coming year. Yearly reviews provide perspective that's impossible to gain from shorter time frames. They help identify patterns, celebrate growth, and realign with core values and priorities.

concepts.name: CODE Method
concepts.summary: Capture, Organize, Distill, Express - a knowledge management workflow.
concepts.explanation: The CODE Method from Tiago Forte's Building a Second Brain framework describes the four stages of personal knowledge management: Capture (save valuable information), Organize (store it for actionability), Distill (extract the essence), and Express (share and create from your knowledge). This workflow transforms passive consumption into active knowledge creation. Each stage has specific practices and the full cycle ensures knowledge doesn't just accumulate but becomes useful.

concepts.name: Transfer Learning
concepts.summary: Applying knowledge from one domain to accelerate learning in another.
concepts.explanation: Transfer Learning is the ability to apply knowledge, skills, and patterns from one domain to accelerate learning in another. When diving into a new field or topic, recognizing familiar patterns helps learn faster. A programmer learning a new language leverages existing programming concepts; a musician learning a new instrument applies music theory. Building a rich knowledge base enables more transfer learning opportunities. Connected notes make cross-domain patterns more visible.

concepts.name: Unlearning
concepts.summary: The process of discarding outdated or incorrect knowledge and habits.
concepts.explanation: Unlearning is the process of consciously discarding outdated, incorrect, or unhelpful knowledge, habits, and mental models. As the world changes and our understanding grows, some things we 'know' become obsolete or wrong. Unlearning things is as important as learning new ones. The challenge is that old patterns are deeply ingrained. PKM helps by making beliefs explicit so they can be examined and updated. Evergreen notes should evolve, and sometimes that means removing outdated content.

concepts.name: Meta-Learning
concepts.summary: Learning how to learn - understanding and optimizing your learning process.
concepts.explanation: Meta-Learning is the practice of learning how to learn - understanding your own learning process and optimizing it. It involves knowing which strategies work best for different types of material, recognizing when you're not understanding, and adjusting approaches accordingly. Meta-learning is the missing link in education that schools often don't teach. Developing meta-learning skills accelerates all other learning. PKM systems support meta-learning by making the learning process visible and reflectable.

concepts.name: Task Batching
concepts.summary: Grouping similar tasks together to reduce context switching.
concepts.explanation: Task Batching is the practice of grouping similar tasks together and completing them in dedicated time blocks. Instead of handling emails throughout the day, batch all email processing into specific times. Instead of making phone calls as they come up, designate a calling block. Batching reduces context switching costs, enables deeper focus, and improves efficiency. The mental setup required for a task type is done once rather than repeatedly.

concepts.name: Timeboxing
concepts.summary: Allocating fixed time periods to specific tasks regardless of completion.
concepts.explanation: Timeboxing is the practice of allocating a fixed, maximum amount of time to a task and working on it only during that time regardless of whether it's complete. Unlike time blocking (which reserves time), timeboxing limits time. This creates urgency, prevents perfectionism, and ensures important tasks don't consume unlimited time. When the timebox ends, you move on - even if unfinished. Timeboxing is particularly useful for open-ended tasks that could expand indefinitely.

concepts.name: Mental Energy
concepts.summary: The cognitive resources available for thinking, deciding, and creating.
concepts.explanation: Mental Energy refers to the finite cognitive resources available for focused thinking, decision-making, creativity, and willpower. Like physical energy, mental energy depletes with use and requires recovery. Decision fatigue, cognitive load, and sustained focus all consume mental energy. PKM helps conserve mental energy by externalizing information (reducing memory load), providing structure (reducing decisions), and enabling efficient retrieval (reducing search effort). Managing mental energy is key to productivity.

concepts.name: Sunk Cost Fallacy
concepts.summary: Continuing investments due to past costs that cannot be recovered.
concepts.explanation: The Sunk Cost Fallacy is the tendency to continue an endeavor because of previously invested resources (time, money, effort) that cannot be recovered, rather than evaluating future costs and benefits. 'I've already put so much into this' becomes justification for continuing even when stopping is rational. In PKM, this might manifest as reluctance to abandon an elaborate system that isn't working or clinging to notes you'll never use just because you spent time creating them.

concepts.name: Anchoring Bias
concepts.summary: Over-relying on the first piece of information encountered.
concepts.explanation: Anchoring Bias is the tendency to rely too heavily on the first piece of information encountered (the 'anchor') when making decisions. Subsequent judgments are made by adjusting from the anchor, but adjustments are typically insufficient. Initial prices, first impressions, and early information disproportionately influence final conclusions. Awareness of anchoring helps in negotiations, research, and decision-making by prompting consideration of whether initial information is unduly influencing conclusions.

concepts.name: Hindsight Bias
concepts.summary: The tendency to see past events as having been predictable.
concepts.explanation: Hindsight Bias is the tendency, after an event has occurred, to see it as having been predictable even when there was no way to predict it. 'I knew it all along.' This bias distorts memory and makes us overconfident in our ability to predict future events. For learning and PKM, hindsight bias can make us undervalue documentation - we forget how uncertain things were at decision time. Capturing reasoning contemporaneously preserves the actual uncertainty faced.

concepts.name: Planning Fallacy
concepts.summary: The tendency to underestimate time, costs, and risks while overestimating benefits.
concepts.explanation: The Planning Fallacy is the tendency to underestimate time, costs, and risks of future actions while overestimating their benefits. Projects almost always take longer and cost more than initially estimated. This bias persists even when we know about past overruns. Counterstrategies include: using reference class forecasting (basing estimates on similar past projects), breaking projects into small tasks, adding buffers, and tracking actual versus estimated times to calibrate future estimates.

concepts.name: Availability Heuristic
concepts.summary: Judging likelihood based on how easily examples come to mind.
concepts.explanation: The Availability Heuristic is a mental shortcut where we judge the probability or frequency of events based on how easily examples come to mind. Vivid, recent, or emotionally charged events seem more common than they actually are. Plane crashes feel more dangerous than car accidents because they're more memorable. In PKM, notes that are more recently accessed or more dramatically written may seem more important than they are. Systematic tagging and organization help counter this bias.

concepts.name: Loss Aversion
concepts.summary: The pain of losing is psychologically stronger than the pleasure of gaining.
concepts.explanation: Loss Aversion is the psychological phenomenon where the pain of losing something is about twice as powerful as the pleasure of gaining the equivalent. We are more motivated to avoid losses than to acquire gains. This influences decision-making and risk tolerance. In PKM, loss aversion may make us reluctant to delete notes (even useless ones) or abandon systems we've invested in. Recognizing this bias helps make more rational decisions about what to keep.

concepts.name: Status Quo Bias
concepts.summary: Preference for the current state of affairs over change.
concepts.explanation: Status Quo Bias is the preference for maintaining the current state of affairs rather than changing, even when change would be beneficial. The default option is favored simply because it's the default. This explains resistance to switching tools, updating processes, or revising notes even when improvements are possible. While some stability is valuable, being aware of status quo bias helps evaluate whether current practices truly serve you or are just comfortable habits.

concepts.name: Goal Setting
concepts.summary: The process of defining objectives and creating plans to achieve them.
concepts.explanation: Goal Setting is the process of defining specific, measurable objectives and creating actionable plans to achieve them. Effective goals are often SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound. Goals provide direction, motivation, and benchmarks for progress. PKM systems support goal setting through tracking, regular reviews, and connecting daily actions to larger objectives. Goals should be captured, reviewed periodically, and adjusted as circumstances change.

concepts.name: Reflective Thinking
concepts.summary: Deliberate contemplation of experiences and knowledge to gain insight.
concepts.explanation: Reflective Thinking is the practice of deliberately contemplating experiences, actions, and knowledge to gain deeper insight and learning. It involves stepping back from activity to consider what happened, why it happened, and what can be learned. Reflection transforms experience into understanding. Journaling, periodic reviews, and deliberate note-reviewing sessions all support reflective thinking. Without reflection, we risk repeating mistakes and missing opportunities for growth.

concepts.name: Associative Thinking
concepts.summary: Connecting ideas through relationships and similarities.
concepts.explanation: Associative Thinking is the cognitive process of connecting ideas, concepts, and memories through relationships, similarities, and connections. The brain naturally works through associations - one thought triggers related thoughts. PKM tools that emphasize linking and backlinks leverage associative thinking. Mind maps, connected notes, and knowledge graphs all support natural associative exploration. Creative insights often emerge from unexpected associations between seemingly unrelated ideas.

concepts.name: Radiant Thinking
concepts.summary: Thinking that radiates outward from a central concept through associations.
concepts.explanation: Radiant Thinking, a concept from Tony Buzan, describes the brain's natural pattern of thinking that radiates outward from a central idea through countless associations in all directions. Like light rays emanating from a source, thoughts branch and connect endlessly. Mind maps are designed to capture radiant thinking visually. Understanding radiant thinking helps design PKM systems that align with how the brain naturally processes and connects information.

concepts.name: Serendipity
concepts.summary: Fortunate unexpected discoveries that emerge from good systems.
concepts.explanation: Serendipity in PKM refers to the fortunate unexpected discoveries and connections that emerge when exploring a well-connected knowledge base. It's finding valuable information you weren't looking for, or realizing connections between ideas you hadn't considered. Good PKM systems increase serendipity through linking, random surfacing, and graph exploration. Serendipity isn't pure luck - it's prepared luck that comes from having organized, connected information that can reveal surprises.

concepts.name: Just-in-Time Learning
concepts.summary: Learning what you need precisely when you need it.
concepts.explanation: Just-in-Time Learning is the practice of acquiring knowledge exactly when you need it rather than studying in advance 'just in case.' Instead of front-loading learning, you learn on demand as needs arise. This approach is efficient (no wasted learning), relevant (immediate application), and motivating (clear purpose). PKM systems support just-in-time learning by providing quick access to reference material when needed. The key is knowing where to find information, not memorizing everything.

concepts.name: Processing Notes
concepts.summary: The workflow of transforming raw captures into organized, connected knowledge.
concepts.explanation: Processing Notes refers to the workflow of transforming raw captures (fleeting notes, highlights, quick thoughts) into organized, connected knowledge (literature notes, permanent notes). This is where the real work of PKM happens - not just capturing but actively working with information. Processing includes: reviewing captures, extracting key ideas, writing in your own words, creating connections, and filing appropriately. Regular processing prevents backlogs and ensures captures become usable knowledge.

concepts.name: Refactoring Notes
concepts.summary: Restructuring and improving notes without changing their essential meaning.
concepts.explanation: Refactoring Notes, borrowed from software development, is the practice of restructuring and improving notes without changing their essential meaning or content. This includes: splitting large notes into atomic ones, merging redundant notes, improving clarity, adding links, updating outdated information, and reorganizing structure. Like code refactoring, note refactoring improves maintainability and usefulness. The Boy Scout Rule encourages small refactorings during regular use.

concepts.name: Obsidian Canvas
concepts.summary: An infinite visual workspace for spatial thinking and idea arrangement.
concepts.explanation: Obsidian Canvas is an infinite visual workspace in Obsidian for spatial thinking, idea arrangement, and visual connection of notes. It allows you to place notes, images, PDFs, and other content on a 2D canvas and draw connections between them. Canvas supports visual thinking, brainstorming, project planning, and exploring relationships between ideas spatially. It bridges traditional note-taking with visual/spatial thinking approaches like mind mapping.

concepts.name: Dataview
concepts.summary: A query engine for treating Obsidian notes as a database.
concepts.explanation: Dataview is an Obsidian plugin that allows you to query your notes as if they were a database. Using a query language, you can create dynamic views, lists, tables, and task trackers from note metadata. This transforms a static vault into a dynamic knowledge system. Use cases include: creating project dashboards, listing all notes with specific tags, tracking reading lists, and generating dynamic MOCs. Dataview makes notes searchable and actionable in powerful ways.

concepts.name: Mental Context
concepts.summary: The cognitive state and loaded information needed for a specific task.
concepts.explanation: Mental Context refers to the cognitive state, loaded information, and mental setup required to work effectively on a specific task or project. Loading a mental context takes time as you recall relevant information, understand current state, and get into the right mindset. Context switching destroys this loaded context. PKM helps preserve mental context through documentation - capturing the current state, next steps, and relevant information so it can be quickly restored after interruptions.

articles.title: Saving and restoring mental contexts to improve mental health and productivity

concepts.name: Parkinson's Law
concepts.summary: Work expands to fill the time available for its completion.
concepts.explanation: Parkinson's Law states that work expands to fill the time available for its completion. If you give yourself a week to complete a two-hour task, it will somehow take a week. This insight supports timeboxing and deadline setting - constraints actually increase productivity rather than limiting it. Without deadlines, tasks can expand indefinitely. Setting artificial constraints on open-ended work prevents endless refinement and ensures progress.

concepts.name: Hofstadter's Law
concepts.summary: Things always take longer than expected, even accounting for the law itself.
concepts.explanation: Hofstadter's Law states: 'It always takes longer than you expect, even when you take into account Hofstadter's Law.' This self-referential adage captures the persistent tendency to underestimate task duration despite knowing about underestimation. Related to the planning fallacy, it's a humbling reminder to add generous buffers to estimates. For PKM projects like building a system, expect it to take longer than planned and design for incremental progress rather than complete transformation.

concepts.name: Elaborative Interrogation
concepts.summary: Learning by asking 'why' and 'how' questions about information.
concepts.explanation: Elaborative Interrogation is a learning technique that involves asking 'why' and 'how' questions about the information you're learning. Instead of passively accepting facts, you actively probe the reasons behind them. 'Why is this true?' 'How does this work?' 'Why does this matter?' This questioning deepens understanding by connecting new information to existing knowledge. It's especially effective for factual learning and creating richer, more meaningful notes.

concepts.name: Generation Effect
concepts.summary: Information is better remembered when generated than when merely read.
concepts.explanation: The Generation Effect is the phenomenon where information is better remembered when you generate or create it yourself rather than simply reading or receiving it. Writing notes in your own words, creating your own examples, and producing summaries all leverage the generation effect. This is why copying verbatim is less effective than paraphrasing, and why creating your own knowledge is more valuable than just collecting others' ideas.

concepts.name: Desirable Difficulties
concepts.summary: Learning challenges that slow initial performance but enhance long-term retention.
concepts.explanation: Desirable Difficulties are learning conditions that make initial learning harder but ultimately enhance long-term retention and transfer. Examples include: testing yourself instead of re-reading (active recall), spacing practice over time (spaced repetition), mixing topics (interleaving), and generating answers rather than reading them (generation effect). These difficulties feel harder in the moment but produce superior learning. Easy learning often means shallow learning.

concepts.name: Encoding
concepts.summary: The process of converting information into memory traces.
concepts.explanation: Encoding is the cognitive process of converting perceived information into memory traces that can later be retrieved. How information is encoded affects how well it's remembered. Deep encoding (connecting to existing knowledge, elaborating, visualizing) creates stronger memories than shallow encoding (rote repetition, surface features). PKM practices like writing in your own words, making connections, and using templates all support effective encoding of knowledge.

concepts.name: Working Memory
concepts.summary: The limited-capacity system for temporarily holding and manipulating information.
concepts.explanation: Working Memory is the cognitive system responsible for temporarily holding and manipulating information needed for complex cognitive tasks. It has limited capacity - typically 4-7 items - and information decays quickly without rehearsal. Working memory is the 'mental workspace' where thinking happens. PKM systems extend working memory by externalizing information, allowing you to offload details and free up mental space for higher-order thinking. This is why 'your brain is for having ideas, not holding them.'

concepts.name: Retrieval
concepts.summary: The process of accessing and bringing stored information into consciousness.
concepts.explanation: Retrieval is the cognitive process of accessing stored memories and bringing them into conscious awareness. Unlike a computer, human retrieval is reconstructive - we rebuild memories rather than playing them back exactly. Retrieval is strengthened by practice (the testing effect) and is highly dependent on cues. PKM systems are essentially retrieval systems - they provide cues (links, tags, search) to help you access stored knowledge. Good organization optimizes retrieval.

concepts.name: Personal Manifesto
concepts.summary: A written declaration of your values, principles, and guiding beliefs.
concepts.explanation: A Personal Manifesto is a written declaration that articulates your core values, personal principles, beliefs, and commitments. It serves as a guiding document for making decisions aligned with who you are and who you want to become. Creating a manifesto requires deep reflection on what matters most to you. Once documented, it provides clarity during difficult decisions and helps maintain integrity between beliefs and actions. It's a living document that evolves as you grow.

concepts.name: Ikigai
concepts.summary: The Japanese concept of 'reason for being' - finding purpose at the intersection of passion, mission, profession, and vocation.
concepts.explanation: Ikigai is a Japanese concept meaning 'reason for being.' It represents the intersection of four elements: what you love (passion), what you're good at (profession), what the world needs (mission), and what you can be paid for (vocation). Finding your ikigai means discovering work that is deeply fulfilling, valuable to others, and sustainable. It's not about finding a single answer but exploring how these elements interact in your life and career.

concepts.name: Life Design
concepts.summary: Applying design thinking principles to intentionally create your ideal life.
concepts.explanation: Life Design applies design thinking principles to the challenge of creating a meaningful, fulfilling life. Rather than letting life happen to you, you actively prototype, iterate, and design your path. Key practices include: defining what 'a well-lived life' means to you, generating multiple possible futures, prototyping through small experiments, and iterating based on what you learn. Life Design treats life as a design problem to be solved creatively, not a problem to be optimized.

references.title: Designing Your Life by Bill Burnett & Dave Evans

concepts.name: DIKW Pyramid
concepts.summary: A hierarchy showing the progression from Data to Information to Knowledge to Wisdom.
concepts.explanation: The DIKW Pyramid represents the progression from raw data to ultimate wisdom. Data is raw facts and figures without context. Information is data organized and given meaning. Knowledge is information integrated with understanding, enabling application. Wisdom is the application of knowledge with judgment and ethics. PKM is fundamentally about climbing this pyramid - transforming the information we consume into actionable knowledge and, ultimately, wisdom that guides good decisions.

concepts.name: Tools for Thought
concepts.summary: Software and methods designed to augment human thinking and knowledge work.
concepts.explanation: Tools for Thought (TfT) are technologies and methods designed to augment human cognition, memory, and reasoning. The term encompasses note-taking apps, mind mapping tools, spaced repetition systems, and any software that enhances thinking capabilities. Modern examples include Obsidian, Roam Research, and Notion. The key insight is that good tools don't just store information - they shape how you think. Choosing and configuring your TfT is a significant decision for knowledge workers.

concepts.name: Shiny Object Syndrome
concepts.summary: The tendency to chase new tools and methods instead of mastering current ones.
concepts.explanation: Shiny Object Syndrome is the tendency to constantly chase new tools, methods, or systems instead of mastering and consistently using what you have. In PKM, it manifests as tool-hopping - endlessly switching between note-taking apps, always convinced the next tool will solve all problems. This prevents developing deep fluency with any system. The antidote is commitment: pick a good-enough tool and stick with it long enough to develop real proficiency before evaluating alternatives.

concepts.name: Eisenhower Matrix
concepts.summary: A prioritization framework using urgency and importance to categorize tasks.
concepts.explanation: The Eisenhower Matrix (also called Urgent-Important Matrix) is a prioritization framework that categorizes tasks along two dimensions: urgency and importance. This creates four quadrants: Q1 (Urgent & Important) - do immediately; Q2 (Not Urgent & Important) - schedule time for; Q3 (Urgent & Not Important) - delegate if possible; Q4 (Not Urgent & Not Important) - eliminate. The key insight is spending more time in Q2 (strategic, important work) reduces time spent in Q1 (crisis mode).

concepts.name: Morning Routine
concepts.summary: A structured sequence of activities to start your day intentionally.
concepts.explanation: A Morning Routine is a structured sequence of activities performed at the start of each day. Good morning routines set the tone for productive, intentional days. Common elements include: exercise, meditation, journaling, planning, and learning. The key is consistency - doing the same things in the same order reduces decision fatigue and creates momentum. Morning routines leverage willpower when it's highest and establish patterns that carry through the day.

concepts.name: Evening Routine
concepts.summary: A structured sequence of activities to end your day and prepare for tomorrow.
concepts.explanation: An Evening Routine is a structured sequence of activities performed at the end of each day. Good evening routines promote quality rest and set up the next day for success. Common elements include: reviewing the day, capturing loose thoughts, planning tomorrow, unwinding activities, and sleep preparation. Evening routines help close open loops, process the day's experiences, and transition from work mode to rest mode, enabling better sleep and recovery.

concepts.name: Most Important Task
concepts.summary: Identifying and completing your highest-impact task early each day.
concepts.explanation: The Most Important Task (MIT) technique involves identifying the single most impactful task for the day and completing it first, before getting pulled into reactive work. This ensures that even if nothing else gets done, you've moved the needle on what matters most. The MIT is typically the task that, if completed, would make the day feel successful. Combining MIT with morning routines creates powerful momentum for productive days.

references.title: Make Time by Jake Knapp & John Zeratsky

concepts.name: 3-3-3 Method
concepts.summary: A daily structure: 3 hours on one project, 3 shorter tasks, 3 maintenance activities.
concepts.explanation: The 3-3-3 Method is a daily productivity structure: spend 3 hours on your most important project (deep work), complete 3 shorter tasks (30 minutes or less each), and handle 3 maintenance activities (email, admin, etc.). This creates balanced days that advance significant work while handling necessary smaller tasks. The structure prevents both extremes - neither neglecting deep work for busywork nor ignoring essential maintenance while chasing big projects.

concepts.name: Forcing Function
concepts.summary: Constraints or mechanisms that compel specific behaviors or outcomes.
concepts.explanation: A Forcing Function is any mechanism, commitment, or constraint that compels you to take action or behave in a certain way. Examples include: deadlines (forcing completion), public commitments (forcing follow-through), and physical environment design (forcing behaviors). In PKM, periodic reviews are forcing functions for processing notes. The power of forcing functions is that they remove the need for willpower - the structure itself drives the behavior.

concepts.name: Systems Thinking
concepts.summary: Understanding how components interact within complex wholes.
concepts.explanation: Systems Thinking is an approach that views problems as parts of larger, interconnected systems rather than isolated events. It focuses on understanding relationships, feedback loops, and emergent behaviors. In PKM, systems thinking means understanding how your notes, tools, processes, and habits all interact. Changes in one area ripple through the system. Good PKM design considers the whole system, not just individual components. Systems thinking prevents optimizing parts while degrading the whole.

references.title: Thinking in Systems by Donella Meadows

concepts.name: Kaizen
concepts.summary: The Japanese philosophy of continuous incremental improvement.
concepts.explanation: Kaizen is the Japanese philosophy of continuous improvement through small, incremental changes. Rather than seeking dramatic transformations, kaizen focuses on making things slightly better every day. The improvements compound over time. In PKM, kaizen means regularly refining your system - improving a template, adding useful tags, cleaning up outdated notes. The Boy Scout Rule embodies kaizen: leave things better than you found them. Sustainable progress beats sporadic overhauls.

concepts.name: Interstitial Journaling
concepts.summary: Capturing thoughts and notes in the gaps between tasks throughout the day.
concepts.explanation: Interstitial Journaling is the practice of writing brief journal entries in the transitions between tasks throughout your day. Instead of dedicated journaling sessions, you capture thoughts, document what you just completed, and note what you're about to do in these interstitial moments. This approach maintains awareness of how you spend time, captures ideas before they're lost, and creates a detailed record without requiring lengthy writing sessions. It integrates journaling into your workflow rather than adding it as a separate task.

concepts.name: Morning Pages
concepts.summary: Three pages of stream-of-consciousness writing first thing each morning.
concepts.explanation: Morning Pages, from Julia Cameron's 'The Artist's Way,' involves writing three pages of longhand, stream-of-consciousness writing first thing every morning. There's no topic or structure - you write whatever comes to mind. The practice clears mental clutter, surfaces subconscious thoughts, and primes creativity. Morning pages aren't meant to be good writing - they're a brain dump that empties the mind and often reveals insights, worries, or ideas you didn't know you had.

references.title: The Artist's Way by Julia Cameron

concepts.name: Knowledge Ingestion Process
concepts.summary: The systematic workflow for processing consumed content into your knowledge system.
concepts.explanation: The Knowledge Ingestion Process is your systematic workflow for transforming consumed content (books, articles, podcasts, videos, conversations) into useful knowledge in your PKM system. It typically includes: capturing highlights and reactions, processing captures during review periods, distilling key insights, writing notes in your own words, connecting to existing knowledge, and filing appropriately. Without a defined ingestion process, content consumption doesn't translate into usable knowledge.

concepts.name: Capture Habit
concepts.summary: The trained behavior of immediately capturing thoughts, ideas, and information.
concepts.explanation: The Capture Habit is the trained behavior of immediately capturing thoughts, ideas, and information before they're forgotten. It's the foundation of effective PKM. The habit requires: having capture tools always accessible, low friction for creating captures, and trust that captured items will be processed. Without the capture habit, valuable ideas are lost constantly. With it, your knowledge system grows continuously. Building this habit takes deliberate practice until it becomes automatic.

concepts.name: AI Assistants
concepts.summary: AI tools configured to help with specific tasks like writing, research, or coding.
concepts.explanation: AI Assistants are AI-powered tools configured to help with specific tasks such as writing, research, coding, or analysis. Modern AI assistants like Claude, ChatGPT, and others can be customized through system prompts to understand your context, style, and needs. PKM enhances AI assistance by providing rich context - your notes become training data for personalized AI interactions. Well-crafted AI assistants multiply your capabilities in areas where AI excels.

concepts.name: AI Master Prompt
concepts.summary: A comprehensive system prompt that configures AI to understand your context and work style.
concepts.explanation: An AI Master Prompt is a comprehensive system prompt designed to configure AI assistants with deep understanding of your context, preferences, expertise, writing style, and goals. It typically includes: who you are, your expertise areas, your communication preferences, your values, and guidelines for how the AI should behave. A well-crafted AI Master Prompt transforms generic AI into a personalized assistant that produces consistently relevant, appropriately-styled outputs.

concepts.name: Prompt Engineering
concepts.summary: The practice of crafting effective prompts to get optimal results from AI models.
concepts.explanation: Prompt Engineering is the practice of crafting effective prompts to get optimal results from AI language models. It involves understanding how AI models interpret instructions and structuring prompts for clarity, context, and desired output format. Techniques include: providing examples (few-shot learning), specifying output format, breaking complex tasks into steps, and giving clear constraints. Good prompt engineering dramatically improves AI output quality and is becoming an essential skill for knowledge workers.

concepts.name: Model Context Protocol
concepts.summary: A standard for connecting AI models with external data sources and tools.
concepts.explanation: The Model Context Protocol (MCP) is an open standard developed by Anthropic for connecting AI models with external data sources and tools. It enables AI assistants to access your PKM system, files, databases, and other resources through a standardized interface. MCP allows AI to work with your actual data rather than just what you paste into prompts. This bridges the gap between AI capabilities and your personal knowledge, enabling more contextual and useful AI assistance.

concepts.name: Five Whys Technique
concepts.summary: Asking 'why' repeatedly to drill down to root causes.
concepts.explanation: The Five Whys Technique is a problem-solving method where you repeatedly ask 'why' (typically five times) to drill down from symptoms to root causes. Originally from Toyota's manufacturing process, it's effective for personal reflection too. When facing a problem or trying to understand your motivations, asking 'why' repeatedly uncovers deeper layers. The technique prevents treating symptoms while ignoring underlying causes and helps identify leverage points for meaningful change.

concepts.name: Paradox of Choice
concepts.summary: Having too many options leads to anxiety and decision paralysis.
concepts.explanation: The Paradox of Choice describes how having too many options, rather than increasing satisfaction, often leads to anxiety, decision paralysis, and reduced satisfaction with whatever is chosen. More choices mean more opportunity cost awareness, more comparison, and more regret potential. In PKM, this manifests as overwhelm when facing too many tools, methods, or organizational structures. The antidote is deliberately limiting options and making irreversible choices that eliminate alternatives.

references.title: The Paradox of Choice by Barry Schwartz

concepts.name: Time Horizons
concepts.summary: Different time scales for planning, from daily tasks to lifetime goals.
concepts.explanation: Time Horizons are different time scales used for planning and organizing work, from immediate (today, this week) to long-term (years, decades, lifetime). Effective personal organization aligns activities across horizons - daily tasks should connect to weekly goals, which connect to monthly objectives, which connect to yearly ambitions, which connect to life goals. Different horizons require different thinking modes: tactical for short-term, strategic for long-term. Regular reviews bridge horizons.

concepts.name: Content Curation
concepts.summary: Selecting, organizing, and presenting valuable content from various sources.
concepts.explanation: Content Curation is the process of discovering, gathering, organizing, and sharing the most relevant content on specific topics. Unlike content creation (making original content), curation involves filtering, adding context, and presenting existing content in valuable ways. Good curation saves others time by surfacing quality material. In PKM, you curate content for yourself first - collecting and organizing valuable resources. This curation can then become the basis for sharing with others.

concepts.name: Ivy Lee Method
concepts.summary: A simple productivity method: list 6 tasks, rank by priority, complete in order.
concepts.explanation: The Ivy Lee Method is a simple productivity technique from 1918. At the end of each day: write down six tasks for tomorrow, prioritize them in order of importance, and the next day work through them in order, not moving to the next until the current one is complete. Unfinished tasks move to tomorrow's list. The power is in its simplicity - forced prioritization, single-tasking, and carrying forward unfinished work. Sometimes the simplest methods are most effective.

concepts.name: Gravity Problems
concepts.summary: Problems that can't be solved because they're fundamental constraints of reality.
concepts.explanation: Gravity Problems are problems that cannot be solved because they're fundamental constraints - like gravity, they're simply facts of reality that must be accepted rather than fought. In life design, gravity problems are situations you can't change: past events, other people's choices, market conditions, or physical limitations. Recognizing gravity problems is crucial because energy spent fighting them is wasted. The skill is distinguishing between problems you can solve and gravity problems you must accept and work around.

concepts.name: Information Management
concepts.summary: The systematic organization, storage, and retrieval of information.
concepts.explanation: Information Management (IM) is the systematic collection, organization, storage, and retrieval of information. It's broader than PKM - encompassing all information handling, not just personal knowledge. Good IM means knowing where to store information, how to organize it, and how to find it when needed. It includes file systems, email management, digital assets, and documentation. IM provides the infrastructure that PKM builds upon. Without solid IM, PKM efforts are undermined by information chaos.

concepts.name: Inbox Zero
concepts.summary: Keeping inboxes empty by processing items to appropriate destinations.
concepts.explanation: Inbox Zero is the practice of regularly processing inboxes to empty (or near-empty). The key insight is that inboxes are for receiving, not storing. Each item should be processed to a destination: deleted, delegated, done immediately (if quick), deferred (with a reminder), or filed. The goal isn't zero emails but zero unprocessed items. This principle applies beyond email to any inbox: notes inbox, task inbox, physical inbox. Unprocessed inboxes create stress and hide important items.

concepts.name: Limit Work In Progress
concepts.summary: Restricting the number of concurrent tasks to improve focus and throughput.
concepts.explanation: Limiting Work In Progress (WIP) means restricting the number of tasks or projects you're actively working on at any time. Counterintuitively, doing fewer things simultaneously increases overall throughput. WIP limits reduce context switching, improve focus, and expose bottlenecks. In Kanban, WIP limits are explicit - columns have maximum item counts. For personal productivity, this might mean: only 3 active projects, only 1 major task per day, or only moving to new work when current work is complete.

concepts.name: SMART Goals
concepts.summary: Goals that are Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, and Time-bound.
concepts.explanation: SMART Goals is a framework for setting effective goals. Goals should be: Specific (clearly defined), Measurable (quantifiable progress), Achievable (realistic given resources), Relevant (aligned with larger objectives), and Time-bound (with deadlines). Vague goals like 'get better at writing' become SMART: 'Publish one blog post per week for the next 3 months.' SMART criteria transform wishes into actionable commitments with clear success criteria.

concepts.name: 12 Favorite Problems
concepts.summary: Maintaining a list of important questions that guide your learning and work.
concepts.explanation: The 12 Favorite Problems concept, attributed to Richard Feynman, involves maintaining a list of important questions or problems that fascinate you. As you encounter new information, you test it against these problems - does it help solve any of them? This practice turns passive learning into active problem-solving. Your favorite problems guide reading choices, spark creative connections, and give direction to your knowledge accumulation. They're questions you return to repeatedly throughout your life.
